channel.title: Data Is Plural
channel.description: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.03.17 edition
item.description: Disasters, nursing-home staffing, Brazilâ€™s vaccination registry, probable news quotations, and British millionaires of the late 1920s.
item.content:encoded:
Disasters, nursing-home staffing, Brazilâ€™s vaccination registry, probable news quotations, and British millionaires of the late 1920s.

Â 

Disasters. The Emergency Events Database (EM-DAT) contains â€œessential core data on the occurrence and effects of more than 21,000 [natural and technological] disasters in the world, from 1900 to present.â€ It focuses on disasters that have caused 10+ human deaths, affected 100+ people, sparked a state of emergency, and/or prompted a request for international assistance. Where known, the public dataset (registration required) indicates each disasterâ€™s location, type, start/end dates, and estimated damages; the number of people killed, injured, made homeless, or otherwise affected; and more. Related: The Geocoded Disasters (GDIS) Dataset (registration required) provides spatial coordinates for the natural disasters in EM-DAT from 1960 to 2018.

Â 

Nursing-home staffing. The US Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services requires nursing homes to submit detailed payroll information, which the agency converts into public-use files that summarize daily staffing levels at each facility. The files count employee and contract hours for dozens of types of staff, ranging from administrators to respiratory therapists. Related: â€œMaggots, Rape and Yet Five Stars: How U.S. Ratings of Nursing Homes Mislead the Public,â€ a recent New York Times investigation that uses the data in several ways.

Â 

Brazilâ€™s vaccination registry. Brazilâ€™s health ministry is publishing granular data from its COVID-19 vaccination registry, with data on more than 12 million doses administered so far. For each dose, it indicates the patientâ€™s date of birth, sex, race, location, and eligibility group; the vaccine name, manufacturer, and lot; the date and location of vaccination; and more. [h/t Olivier Lejeune]

Â 

Probable news quotations. Quotebank is â€œan open corpus of 178 million quotations attributed to the speakers who uttered them, extracted from 162 million English news articles published between 2008 and 2020.â€ Its authors used machine learning to identify the quotes and speakers, â€œcorrectly [attributing] 86.9% of quotations in our experiments.â€ The five most-quoted people: Barack Obama, Donald Trump, Mitt Romney, Hillary Clinton, and Narendra Modi. [h/t Lynn Cherny]

Â 

Early British millionaires. Business historian Peter Scott has reconstructed a dataset of Britainâ€™s â€œinter-war super-rich.â€ Scott started withÂ an official (but mostly nameless) list of 438 â€œmillionairesâ€ (which tax authorities defined as people with annual incomes above Â£50,000) from 1928/29, and then cross-referenced the entries with other sources to identify 291 men and 28 women who fit the criteria. [h/t Jain Family Institute]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send super-rich feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Did a friend forward you this edition? Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and explore the archives.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.03.10 edition
item.description: Coronavirus variants, 200+ years of US property density, Black media, parliamentary election designs, and Amsterdamâ€™s bats.
item.content:encoded:
Coronavirus variants, 200+ years of US property density, Black media, parliamentary election designs, and Amsterdamâ€™s bats.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ FYI: After hitting a quota on TinyLetter, Data Is Plural has migrated to the Buttondown newsletter service; this is the first edition sent through it. Also: After 5+ years and 230+ editions, this newsletter finally has a proper website â€”Â data-is-plural.com. Thanks for reading, and please send complaints!

Â 

Coronavirus variants. Outbreak.infoâ€™s mutation situation reports track the prevalence of new strains of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that sparked the COVID-19 pandemic. For each â€œlineage,â€ the reports provide data on the geography, timing, and number of sequenced viral samples that bear the strainâ€™s signature. The project, led by biologists at Scripps Research, is one of many that draw from the genomic data collected by GISAID (DIP 2020.03.11), which also publishes its own variants dashboard. Related: The US CDC is tracking the number of variant cases reported in each state and territory. But theyâ€™re only providing cumulative counts, so USA Today has begun scraping (and backfilling) the data to maintain a historical record. [h/t Betsy Ladyzhets]

Â 

200+ years of US property density. Johannes Uhl et al.â€™s Historical Settlement Data Compilation for the United States contains estimates, for every half decade from 1810 to 2015, of the number of building units and structures in every 250-meter-by-250-meter chunk of the (present-day) contiguous US. The researchers constructed their calculations from the Zillow Transaction and Assessment Dataset, which contains more than 400 million property records and requires researchers to apply for access. Previously: The Global Human Settlement Layer (DIP 2016.11.02). [h/t Rebecca Hersher]

Â 

Black media. The Black Media Initiative, based at the CUNYâ€™s graduate journalism school, has launched an interactive map and database of 300+ newspapers, radio stations, and other â€œmedia outlets across the U.S. that primarily serve Black communities across the diaspora.â€ The information includes locations, formats, publication frequencies, target audiences, ownership categories, and more. [h/t Mike Reilley]

Â 

Parliamentary election designs. The Electoral System Design Database describes the way in which lower-house parliamentarians are chosen, covering 1,300+ such elections in 217 countries and territories since 1991. It specifies the type of system (e.g., â€œfirst-past-the-post,â€ â€œparty block vote,â€ et cetera), the number of tiers of representation, the number of legislators directly elected, and the number of voting members. [h/t Andrew Stewart]

Â 

Amsterdamâ€™s bats. Using a combination of human observation and automated detection, the city of Amsterdam has been mapping its bat population. Its data features more than 6,000 observations, the observation routes, bat-detection device placement and findings, and the cityâ€™s known bat abodes. [h/t Martina Zamboni]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send ultrasonic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Did a friend forward you this edition? Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and explore the archives.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.03.03 edition
item.description: Police misconduct settlements, congressional e-newsletters, California vaccine availability, illegal cheetah commerce, and soil.
item.content:encoded:
Police misconduct settlements, congressional e-newsletters, California vaccine availability, illegal cheetah commerce, and soil.

Â 

Police misconduct settlements. Reporters at FiveThirtyEight and The Marshall Project filed freedom-of-information requests to 50 US cities, asking for data on all civil lawsuits against their police departments/officers â€œthat resulted in a monetary legal settlementâ€ in 2010â€“2019 â€”Â including incident and settlement dates, plaintiff and defendant names, allegation descriptions, amounts awarded, and more. They received full or partial data from 31 of those cities, and found that total payouts exceeded $3 billion. Donâ€™t miss: The data repositoryâ€™s â€œwords of caution,â€ which discourage comparisons between cities. Related: Coauthor Laura Bronnerâ€™s introductory Twitter thread. [h/t Eric Gardner]

Â 

Congressional e-newsletters. For more than a decade, political scientist Lindsey Cormackâ€™s DCinbox project has collected â€œevery official e-newsletter sent by sitting members of the U.S. House and Senate.â€ You can search the corpus online and also download all the emails as a series of CSV files, grouped by month. For each of the 130,000+ mailings, the files provide the date, subject, body, and senderâ€™s Bioguide ID. (April 2020 was the highest-volume month, with more than 2,300 messages, nearly all of them mentioning the coronavirus.)

Â 

California vaccine availability. The volunteer-driven VaccinateCA project calls â€œhundreds of potential [COVID-19] vaccination sites daily, asking them if they have the vaccine and if so to whom they will administer it to and how to get an appointment.â€ You can examine the results on their website, and also use their API to access the latest data, which includes status reports on every California county, 20+ health care providers, and thousands of potential vaccination sites. Related: â€œWhat Weâ€™ve Learned (So Far).â€ [h/t Simon Willison]

Â 

Illegal cheetah commerce. A team of conservationists has compiled a decade of data on illegal cheetah sales and ownership, drawing from â€œover 300 sources, including direct communications with field informants, veterinarians, and cheetah owners,â€ court records, social media, and more. The dataset covers 1,800+ cases â€”Â including both actual seizures and alleged/suspected incidents â€”Â involving 4,000+ cheetahs or cheetah parts/derivatives.

Â 

Soil. SoilGrids â€œuses state-of-the-art machine learning methods to map the spatial distribution of soil properties across the globe,â€ including organic carbon density, pH, clay content, and more. The maps use data from the World Soil Information Service, which standardizes millions of soil records. Both projects are run by the International Soil Reference and Information Centre, which also catalogs dozens of public-access soil datasets. [h/t Jonathan Whitaker]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send earthy feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.02.24 edition
item.description: Indian court cases, machine learning papers/code/datasets, foreign ministers, Spanish pardons, and Oâ€™Reilly animals.
item.content:encoded:
Indian court cases, machine learning papers/code/datasets, foreign ministers, Spanish pardons, and Oâ€™Reilly animals.

Â 

Indian court cases. The Development Data Lab has gathered data on 81.2 million court cases in Indiaâ€™s lower judiciary between 2010 and 2018, drawn from the countryâ€™s e-Courts platform. Itâ€™s â€œthe largest open-access dataset on judicial proceedings in the world,â€ says project coauthor Aditi Bhowmick. The public dataset contains each caseâ€™s state, district, court, case type, filing and decision dates, defendant and petitioner genders, legal codes, and more. It â€œhas been fully anonymized to prevent the identification of individual judges or litigants,â€ but researchers can apply for more extensive access. [h/t Shruti Rajagopalan]

Â 

Machine learning papers, code, and datasets. Papers with Code cross-references machine learning papers with their datasets, code, and results. The project has connected 56,000+ of those papers to specific code repositories, and assembled a meta-dataset of 3,000+ relevant datasets. The records can be downloaded in bulk or fetched via API. Related: A recent study examining 133 facial-recognition datasets created since 1976; further coverage in MIT Technology Review. Also related: Exposing.ai, which lets you â€œcheck if your Flickr photos were used to build face recognition.â€ [h/t Karsten Johansson]

Â 

Foreign ministers. Hanna BÃ¤ck et al. have built a dataset of 1,000+ foreign ministers â€”Â all officials holding such a post between 1789 and the mid-2010s in â€œthe worldâ€™s 13 former and current great powers.â€ It describes their stints in office and biographical details, such as their marital status, occupational experience, education level, military service, and much more. [h/t Alex Quiroz Flores]

Â 

Spanish pardons. To build El IndultÃ³metro/The Pardonometer, the Civio Foundation has â€œcollected, scraped and classified all the information contained in the [Official State Gazette] on pardons granted in Spain since 1996.â€ You can browse the 10,000+ pardons and commutations online or download the dataset, which describes the initial charges, form of relief, relevant dates, and more. Related: Civioâ€™s (Spanish-language) methodology and reporting on the topic. [h/t Olaya ArgÃ¼eso PÃ©rez]

Â 

Oâ€™Reilly animals. More than 1,000 illustrated animals have graced the covers of Oâ€™Reilly Mediaâ€™s technical books. The publisher hosts an online â€œmenagerieâ€ where you can browse the pairings; it doesnâ€™t provide downloads, but brian d foy, author of several Oâ€™Reilly books, has written a Perl tutorial on how to scrape it, and has shared the results.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send illustrated feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.02.10 edition
item.description: Hyperlocal Biden/Trump results, subnational COVID-19 vaccinations, historical night light, public-sector employment, and Super Bowl ads.
item.content:encoded:
Hyperlocal Biden/Trump results, subnational COVID-19 vaccinations, historical night light, public-sector employment, and Super Bowl ads.

Â 

Hyperlocal Biden/Trump results. To create their â€œExtremely Detailed Map of the 2020 Election,â€ journalists at The Upshot have gathered and standardized the ballot results for more than 100,000 precincts in dozens of states so far â€”Â representing nearly two-thirds of all votes cast. The accompanying GeoJSON dataset indicates the number of votes received by Joe Biden, by Donald Trump, and overall (including third-party and write-in candidates), joined to each precinctâ€™s geographic boundaries. [h/t Kevin Quealy + Ryan Matsumoto]

Â 

Subnational COVID-19 vaccinations. Software developer Lucas RodÃ©s-Guirao is aggregating coronavirus vaccination numbers, over time, by administrative division â€”Â each canton in Switzerland, for example, and each province in Argentina. The project, inspired by Our World In Dataâ€™s country-level dataset (DIP 2020.12.23), currently includes 20+ countries and provides links to the sources. [h/t Olivier Lejeune]

Â 

Historical night light. Researchers have harmonized two major datasets measuring the light visible on Earth at night. The first, from the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program, covers 1992â€“2013. The second, from the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite, covers 2012 onward. The harmonized dataset covers 1992â€“2018 and polishes the data by removing, for example, â€œnoises from aurora, fires, boasts, and other temporal lights.â€ Related: The Colorado School of Minesâ€™ Earth Observation Group, which â€œspecializes in nighttime observations of lights and combustion sources worldwide.â€ [h/t Milos Popovic]

Â 

Public-sector employment. The World Bankâ€™s Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators â€œis a unique new cross-national dataset on public sector employment and wagesâ€ in 130+ countries between 2000 and 2018, based on censuses and household surveys. The datasetâ€™s measurements include the size of this workforce, its demographics, pay disparities versus the private sector, and more. Related: An introductory Twitter thread from coauthor Faisal Baig.

Â 

Super Bowl ads. Journalists at FiveThirtyEight watched 233 Super Bowl ads run by 10 frequently-advertising brands between 2000 and 2020, drawing from superbowl-ads.comâ€™s video archive. Then they categorized each ad according to seven specific questions, which included â€œWas it trying to be funny?â€ and â€œDid it include animals?â€

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send trying-to-be-funny feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.02.03 edition
item.description: Private prisons, detailed elevations, even more mortality data, web trackers, and hockey.
item.content:encoded:
Private prisons, detailed elevations, even more mortality data, web trackers, and hockey.

Â 

Private prisons. Political scientist Anna Gunderson has assembled a longitudinal dataset of private prisons at the federal, state, and local level through 2016. Using decades of financial reports by the two largest operators, plus those by two other companies one later acquired, Gundersonâ€™s dataset identifies each facilityâ€™s name, location, primary customer, capacity, security level, contract information, and more. Related: Last week, President Biden signed an executive order to phase out the federal use of such facilities.

Â 

Detailed elevations. Among its goals, OpenTopography wants to â€œdemocratize online access to high-resolution (meter to sub-meter scale), Earth science-oriented, topography data acquired with lidar and other technologies.â€ The project hosts hundreds of elevation datasets from around the world, available to visualize online and to download. Related: The US Geological Surveyâ€™s 3D Elevation Program aims â€œto provide the first-ever national baseline of consistent high-resolution topographic elevation dataâ€ by 2023, and already publishes a range of subnational datasets. [h/t Ricardo Pereira]

Â 

Even more mortality data. The World Mortality Dataset contains recent â€œall-cause mortalityâ€ counts for 79 countries, aggregated to weekly, monthly, or quarterly totals (depending on availability). Launched last week by researchers Ariel Karlinsky and Dmitry Kobak, the project draws on the Human Mortality Database, EuroStat, and data collected by the New York Times (DIP 2020.05.27); and expands upon it by gathering data from government websites and through direct inquiries. [h/t Dror Guldin]

Â 

Web trackers. DuckDuckGoâ€™s Tracker Radar watches the webâ€™s watchers. The regularly-updated dataset currently covers 36,000+ of the most common third-party domains, and provides â€œdetailed information about their tracking behavior, including prevalence, ownership, fingerprinting behavior, cookie behavior, privacy policy,â€ and more. As seen in: Blacklight, The Markupâ€™s â€œreal-time website privacy inspector,â€ which uses the dataset. [h/t Surya Mattu]

Â 

Hockey. The National Hockey League has an undocumented API. Technologist Drew Hynes is making sense of the dozens of endpoints, which provide data on decades of player stats, game schedules, draft picks, and more. [h/t Jemma Issroff]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send knucklepuck feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.01.27 edition
item.description: Tens of millions of flights, dot-gov characteristics, corporate risk-talk, Euro-polling, and the Codex Atlanticus.
item.content:encoded:
Tens of millions of flights, dot-gov characteristics, corporate risk-talk, Euro-polling, and the Codex Atlanticus.

Â 

Tens of millions of flights. The OpenSky Network crowdsources air traffic data, thanks to members who collect the radio signals that aircraft periodically broadcast. The nonprofit organization has published a â€œCOVID-19 flight dataset,â€ which contains metadata for the tens of millions of flights those members observed in 2019 and 2020, with plans to update the dataset until the pandemic ends. It includes each flightâ€™s call sign, aircraft model type, origin and destination airports, time first and last seen, and more. [h/t Evgeny Pogrebnyak]

Â 

Dot-gov characteristics. The US General Services Administration publishes a list of all registered .gov domains (DIP 2017.01.18). In 2011, 2014, and 2015, open-source advocate Ben Balter used software to scan each federally-managed domain â€œto sniff out information about [their] technology and capabilities.â€ For instance: Do the domains support HTTPS? Do they use Google Analytics? Earlier this month, Balter ran the scan again, â€œto serve as a snapshot of the state of government technology ahead of the incoming Biden administration.â€ You can browse and download the results.

Â 

Corporate risk-talk. The Firm-Level Risk project uses â€œtextual analysis of quarterly earnings conference calls held by more than 11,000 listed firms in 81 countriesâ€ to construct company-by-company â€œmeasures of exposure, risk, and sentiment.â€ The dataset goes back nearly two decades and includes sub-measures for various themes, such as tax policy, Brexit, and COVID-19. [h/t Stephan Hollander]

Â 

Euro-polling. The European Opinion Polls as Open Data repository collects the results of party-preference polls in 34 countries. For each poll, it lists the polling firm and commissioners, when the fieldwork began and ended, its scope and sample size, and the topline numbers for each party. Related: Project maintainer Filip Van Laenen on â€œhow simple things can turn out to be rather complicated.â€ [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

The da Vinci codex. The Codex Atlanticus â€œis the largest existing collection of original drawings and text by Leonardo da Vinciâ€ â€” 1,119 pages assembled by the 16thâ€“century sculptor Pompeo Leoni. Milanâ€™s Biblioteca Ambrosiana and The Visual Agency have created an interactive graphic that lets you explore the pages by year and subject; you can also download that metadata through the graphicâ€™s â€œAbout the projectâ€ section. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send polymathic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.01.20 edition
item.description: US demonstrations and political violence, Capitol siege charges, terms of service, Indiaâ€™s coal mines, and newsletter links.
item.content:encoded:
US demonstrations and political violence, Capitol siege charges, terms of service, Indiaâ€™s coal mines, and newsletter links.

Â 

US demonstrations and political violence. US Crisis Monitor â€œprovides the public with real-time data and analysis on political violence and demonstrations around the country, establishing an evidence base from which to identify risks, hotspots, and available resources to empower local communities in times of crisis.â€ The project, launched last summer as a collaboration between the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (DIP 2017.11.29) and Princeton Universityâ€™s Bridging Divides Initiative,Â now contains information on 20,000+ peaceful protests (the vast majority of entries), violent demonstrations, riots, and other events since April 2020. For each entry, the dataset lists the event type, date, location, groups involved, as well as a brief summary. As seen in: The Policeâ€™s Tepid Response To The Capitol Breach Wasnâ€™t An Aberration (FiveThirtyEight).

Â 

Capitol siege charges. The Program on Extremism at George Washington University is building a â€œcentral database of court records related to the events of January 6, 2021.â€ In addition to linking to the governmentâ€™s criminal complaints, indictments, and other documents, the researchers are publishing a spreadsheet of all people whoâ€™ve been federally charged â€”Â with names, age, gender, home state, and date charged.

Â 

Terms of service. The Office of the French Ambassador for Digital Affairs has been tracking user-agreement documents (such as terms of service and privacy policies) published by 170+ websites, apps, and other bits of software â€” from Airbnb and Google Analytics to The New York Times and Zillow. You can download them all and subscribe to notifications when they change. [h/t Vincent Viers]

Â 

Indiaâ€™s coal mines. Thanks to Indiaâ€™s Right to Information Act, energy researcher Sandeep Pai has compiled a dataset of the countryâ€™s 459 operational coal mines. It includes each mineâ€™s name, location (state, district, latitude, longitude), ownership, production tonnage, and more. Related: Paiâ€™s introductory Twitter thread.

Â 

Newsletter links. Winning the Internet, an experimental newsletter from The Puddingâ€™s Russell Goldenberg, analyzes the hyperlinks found in 100+ link-heavy general-interest newsletters. Last month, Goldenberg published sixth months of the underlying data â€”Â nearly 150,000 newsletter/link/date observations in total.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send hyperlinked feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.01.13 edition
item.description: Electoral attitudes, fishing activity, Bundestag writings, innovation licensing, and chess puzzles.
item.content:encoded:
Electoral attitudes, fishing activity, Bundestag writings, innovation licensing, and chess puzzles.

Â 

Electoral attitudes. The Comparative National Elections Project â€œis a partnership among scholars who have conducted election surveys on five continents,â€ with a focus on understanding the factors that shape votersâ€™ decisions. The projectâ€™s publicly-available datasets include 48 of the surveys, which use a combination of country-specific questions and shared questionnaire â€”Â asking about political news consumption, attitudes towards democracy, interpersonal communications, and other topics. Related: The Comparative Study of Electoral Systems, a similar collaboration with â€œa special emphasis on voting and turnout.â€ [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

Fishing activity. Global Fishing Watch â€”Â initially organized as a collaboration between conservationists and Google â€”Â uses satellite imagery, ship signals, and other sources â€œto visualise, track and share data about global fishing activity in near real-time and for free.â€ The projectâ€™s public datasets (free registration required) examine various aspects of the industry, including the geography of â€œfishing effortâ€ (2012â€“16) and transshipment between vessels. As seen in: â€œWhy the U.K. and EU Are Fighting Over Fishâ€ (Bloomberg). [h/t Nathan Yau]

Â 

Bundestag writings. Political scientists Corinna Kroeber and Tobias Remschel have compiled a dataset of â€œall written communication published by the German Bundestag between 1949 and 2017,â€ unifying datasets released by Germanyâ€™s parliament â€œin a manner easily accessible to researchers applying text analysis.â€ For each of the 131,835 reports, requests, bills, and other documents, the dataset provides the full text, date, author information, and more. Previously: Six million parliamentary speeches from nine countries (DIP 2020.04.29.

Â 

Innovation licensing. Government agencies often commercialize their innovations through â€œtechnology transferâ€ programs, which strike collaboration and licensing agreements with outside parties. NASA provides a technology transfer API for accessing data about its patent portfolio and software catalog; the National Institutes of Health offers a similar API for querying its licensing opportunities. [h/t Tom Folkes]

Â 

Chess puzzles. Lichess is a free, open-source, donation-supported chess server. Its team publishes a database of the rated matches played on its platform (more than 1.7 billion so far, since 2013), which it recently used to revamp its dataset of original chess puzzles. Previously: Chess games from high-level players and tournaments (DIP 2016.02.17).

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send strategic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.01.06 edition
item.description: Megascale coronavirus surveys, commodity-transportation costs, more college sports financing, ten million Jupyter notebooks, and 2020 in haiku.
item.content:encoded:
Megascale coronavirus surveys, commodity-transportation costs, more college sports financing, ten million Jupyter notebooks, and 2020 in haiku.

Â 

Megascale coronavirus surveys. Carnegie Mellon Universityâ€™s epidemiological forecasting group and Facebook have partnered to field a large-scale coronavirus survey in the US; theyâ€™ve collected more than 15 million responses since April 2020. The University of Maryland has formed a similar partnership for an international survey, in which â€œa representative sample of Facebook users is invited on a daily basis to report on symptoms, social distancing behavior, mental health issues, and financial constraintsâ€; millions have also participated. Geographically-aggregated results of the US survey can be downloaded via an online interface or Delphiâ€™s API; the international results are also available via API. Practical example: An analysis of state-by-state mask usage, with code. [h/t Alex Reinhart]

Â 

Commodity-transportation costs. The UN and the World Bank have launched a new interactive map and dataset that quantify the transportation costs for international trade â€”Â country-by-country and broken down by mode of transportation (sea, air, rail, road), trading partner, and commodity. The numbers, based both on directly-reported figures and statistical modelling, include costs overall, per unit, and per unit per kilometer. The project currently covers only 2016, but has plans to expand. [h/t Jan Hoffmann]

Â 

More college sports financing. The College Athletics Financial Information Database, run by the privately-funded Knight Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics, details the annual sources of revenue (such as ticket sales) and expenses (such as coachesâ€™ compensation) for hundreds of schools, based on information self-reported to the NCAA and federal government. Many of the records were obtained via freedom-of-information requests by USA Today and Syracuse University students. [h/t Craig Garthwaite et al.]

Â 

Millions of computational notebooks. In 2017, a team of researchers downloaded and analyzed 1.25 million publicly-available Jupyter notebooks â€”Â documents that weave computational code, output, and text. They also published the notebooks and their related metadata. Inspired by that project, a team at JetBrains recently did a follow-up scan, analyzing and publishing data on nearly 10 million notebooks.

Â 

2020 in haiku. Over the course of 2020, Eli Holder paid workers on Mechanical Turk to turn news headlines into 5/7/5-syllable poems. The result: 2,760 â€œDoom Haikus,â€ which you can browse on a timeline or download in bulk. For each poem, the dataset also includes the original article URL, date processed, headline, and SEO snippet. [h/t Karsten Johansson]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send journo-poetic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. Did a friend forward you this email? Click here to subscribe.
